title: Hairdresser chain Supercuts is on brink of collapse with 1,400 jobs at risk across 223 salons
text:
Supercuts was placed into an insolvency process

Supercuts was placed into an insolvency process

Hairdressing chain Supercuts is on the brink of collapse less than a year after bosses attempted to persuade landlords to give the company heavy rent cuts.

Regis UK, which owns the Supercuts chain, was placed into an insolvency process on Wednesday, Sky News reported.

The business has roughly 1,400 employees across 223 salons and it is thought the sites will continue to trade while a potential buyer is sought.

Restructuring experts at Deloitte are understood to have been called in to look at options for the salon, with a formal announcement expected on Friday.

Supercuts is on the brink of collapse less than a year after bosses attempted to persuade landlords to give the company heavy rent cuts (Pictured: Supercuts in Birmingham)

The decision to appoint administrators could place hundreds of jobs across the country at risk, though an insider told Sky News it is expected a buyer will be found.

Supercuts has been struggling for the last few years and went through a process known as a Company Voluntary Arrangement (CVA) in 2018.

It meant the company could cut its rents in an attempt to stay afloat.

The CVA process has been widely used by several high street names in recent years, including Arcadia, New Look, Mothercare and Carpetright.

But it has faced criticism from some landlords who claim it is being used as a way to cut rents, instead of only being used to prevent a firm from collapsing.

Regis said at the time that a 'perfect storm' of factors, including falling customer numbers and higher wages, had hurt the business.

The business has 1,400 employees across 223 salons and it is thought that the sites will continue to trade while a potential buyer is sought

The CVA saw rent cuts of up to 100 per cent at more than 100 of Regis's 223 stores and concessions.

Supercuts is a subsidiary of Regis Corporation, which also owns Regis Salons, Mia & Maxx, MasterCuts, Cost Cutters, SmartStyle, and First Choice Haircutters in the US.

In the UK, Supercuts salons are owned by private equity firm Regent LP, under a franchise agreement with the American chain.

The company was founded in the San Francisco Bay Area in 1975, by Geoffrey M. Rappaport and Frank E. Emmett.

Supercuts was unable to comment when approached by MailOnline. Deloitte has been contacted for comment.
description: Supercuts was at risk of collapse today, less than a year after bosses attempted to persuade landlords to give the company heavy rent cuts.
